title: The Fisherman and the Golden Fish
author: Alexander Pushkin

content.text: Narrator: In a small, seaside village, where the salty sea air filled the lungs of its residents and the cries of seagulls echoed through the narrow streets, an old fisherman lived with his wife.
Narrator: Their humble cottage stood at the edge of the village, overlooking the endless blue waters of the ocean.
Narrator: The old fisherman, his face weathered and worn, had spent his entire life out at sea, reaping its bounty to make a meager living.
Narrator: On a sunny morning, the old fisherman set out to sea in his small, rickety boat, his eyes scanning the horizon for the day's catch.
Narrator: His wife, a stout woman with a quick wit, stood on the shore, watching her husband disappear into the distance.
Old Fisherman's Wife: (to herself) May the winds be in his favor, and may his nets be full.
Narrator: The old fisherman sailed farther and farther out to sea, the silence broken only by the gentle lapping of the waves against the hull of his boat.
Narrator: As the sun reached its peak, he cast his line into the water and waited.
Old Fisherman: (to himself) Perhaps today will be the day I catch something worthy of a feast.
Narrator: Hours passed, and the old fisherman's patience was rewarded. His line began to tug, and with a mighty heave, he pulled in a glittering golden fish.
Narrator: The fish shone like the sun itself, its scales catching the light and sending shafts of gold dancing across the waves.
Golden Fish: Oh, dear fisherman, I beg of you, spare my life. I am no ordinary fish, and I shall grant you any wish you desire if you but set me free.
Old Fisherman: A talking fish, you say? I must be dreaming. But very well, I shall set you free. What could a poor old man like myself possibly wish for?
Golden Fish: You shall see, kind fisherman. But first, you must release me.
Narrator: The old fisherman, his curiosity piqued, carefully lifted the golden fish from the water and set it free.
Narrator: The fish swam circles around the boat, its golden scales flashing in the sunlight.
Golden Fish: Now, dear fisherman, what is it that you desire? Riches? Fame? A grand house?
Old Fisherman: Oh, no. I think I should like a new trough for my wife. The one we have is old and worn. A new trough would make her happy.
Golden Fish: Your wish is granted, kind fisherman. Return home, and you shall find a new trough awaiting you.
Narrator: The old fisherman sailed back to shore, his heart filled with wonder.
Narrator: As he approached his cottage, he saw that indeed, a new trough stood outside the door, filled with fresh, clean water.
Old Fisherman's Wife: Ah, a new trough! How wonderful! But tell me, old man, how did you come by it?
Old Fisherman: I caught a magical golden fish, and it granted my wish.
Old Fisherman's Wife: A golden fish, you say? And you wished for a trough? You should have wished for something greater!
Old Fisherman's Wife: Go back to the fish and ask for a grand house, with a garden and a courtyard!
Narrator: The old fisherman, reluctant but obedient, set out to sea once more. He called out to the golden fish, which appeared at his side in an instant.
Old Fisherman: My wife is not satisfied with the trough. She desires a grand house, with a garden and a courtyard.
Golden Fish: Very well, dear fisherman. Your wish is granted.
Narrator: The old fisherman returned home to find a grand house standing in place of his humble cottage.
Narrator: His wife, overjoyed, danced through the rooms, admiring the fine furnishings and the beautiful garden.
Old Fisherman's Wife: Ah, this is more like it! But tell me, old man, why did you not ask for something greater still?
Old Fisherman's Wife: Why not ask to be a noble, with a grand estate and many servants?
Narrator: The old fisherman, weary of his wife's demands, set out to sea once more. He called out to the golden fish, which appeared at his side, its patience wearing thin.
Old Fisherman: My wife desires to be a noble, with a grand estate and many servants.
Golden Fish: Very well, dear fisherman. But be warned, your wife's greed will be her downfall.
Narrator: The old fisherman returned home to find himself and his wife transformed into nobles, with a grand estate and many servants.
Narrator: But his wife was not satisfied, even with this great wealth and power.
Old Fisherman's Wife: I am a noble, but I am not the greatest noble of all. I desire to be the queen, with the king at my side.
Narrator: The old fisherman, his heart heavy with sorrow, set out to sea once more. He called out to the golden fish, which appeared at his side, its expression stern.
Old Fisherman: My wife desires to be the queen, with the king at her side.
Golden Fish: Very well, dear fisherman. But be warned, your wife's greed will bring her nothing but sorrow.
Narrator: The old fisherman returned home to find himself and his wife transformed into the king and queen.
Narrator: But his wife, still not satisfied, desired to be the ruler of the sea itself.
Old Fisherman's Wife: I am the queen, but I am not the greatest ruler of all. I desire to be the ruler of the sea, with all its creatures at my command.
Narrator: The old fisherman, his heart filled with despair, set out to sea once more. He called out to the golden fish, which appeared at his side, its anger burning bright.
Golden Fish: You have asked for too much, dear fisherman. Your wife's greed has brought her nothing but sorrow.
Golden Fish: I shall take back all that I have given you, and you shall return to your humble cottage, with nothing but the memories of your foolish desires.
Narrator: And with that, the golden fish vanished, taking with it all the wealth and power it had granted the old fisherman and his wife.
Narrator: They returned to their humble cottage, their hearts filled with regret and sorrow.
Old Fisherman's Wife: Oh, old man, I am sorry for my greed. I was blinded by my desires, and now we have lost everything.
Old Fisherman: It is not too late, my dear wife. We can still live a simple life, and be happy with what we have.

Narrator: And so, the old fisherman and his wife lived out the rest of their days in their humble cottage, their hearts filled with the wisdom of their experiences, and the knowledge that true happiness comes not from wealth or power, but from the simple things in life.
